content.question: The figure above shows the graphs of the polar curves <math alttext="r equals, 1.25 theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="r equals, the cosine cubed of, open parenthesis, 2 theta, close parenthesis, plus 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>cos</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to theta, less than or equal to pi over 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. The two curves intersect at <math alttext="theta equals, 0.8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the area of the shaded region?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.9: (BC ONLY) Finding the Area of the Region Bounded by Two Polar Curves

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
